Plot Summary:
The story follows Cheyenne Harry (Harry Carey), a drifter and cowboy with a reputation for being tough but honorable. Harry arrives in a rough frontier town ruled by corruption and lawlessness, where he befriends Cimmaron Bill (Duke R. Lee) and meets Bess Thurston (Neva Gerber), a young woman trying to survive in a harsh world.

Bess lives under the shadow of her brother, who is entangled in crime and associates with the villainous Beau Ross (Vester Pegg). As Harry grows closer to Bess, he finds himself caught between loyalty to his friends and his growing love for her. When Beau Ross kidnaps Bess and attempts to take her across the desert, Harry pursues them in a desperate race for survival.

Through courage and sacrifice, Harry reaffirms his code of honor, embodying the archetype of the Western hero that would dominate American cinema for decades.

Hell Bent is a cornerstone in the careers of both John Ford and Harry Carey. His understated acting influenced later Western stars, including John Wayne. Supporting actor Hoot Gibson also appeared in Hell Bent, at the start of a career that would make him one of the most popular cowboys of the silent and early sound era.

The film was considered lost for many years, with only fragments known to survive. However, a complete print was eventually discovered in the Czech Film Archive, making restoration and preservation possible. This rediscovery highlighted the importance of film archiving and the fragility of silent cinema history.
